awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Water sustainability in the urban environment: Improving the sustainable use of water through interdisciplinary research
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site is to train students in STEM research projects focused on the sustainable use of water in urban environments. With a growing population, particularly in urban areas, there is increasing demand on water resources. Consequently, it is critical to better understand how this finite resource can be used in a sustainable manner. The REU student participants will investigate how the human interaction with the hydrological environment impacts the sustainability of urban water resources. The interdisciplinary nature of this project illustrates the diversity of science in investigating the various aspects of this environmental issue, including emerging contaminants, urban forest, water reuse, and resilience of water infrastructure. Throughout this process the REU students, with the help of their mentors and coursework, will develop skills for hypotheses generation, design and conduct experiments, as well as analyzing, synthesizing, and communicating their data. 

The goal of this REU Site is to investigate the human-hydrological interface for urban environments with the aim of improving best management practices leading to more sustainable use of urban waters. To achieve this goal, the REU Site will take an interdisciplinary approach. Several research projects based in physical hydrology and biology will investigate the presence, fate and seasonal flux of contaminants into sinkhole lakes and well waters. Researchers in urban hydrology will examine how urban forests and tree canopy reduce stormwater runoff pollution of waterways. An environmental chemistry project will measure levels, chemical profiles, and potential sources of flame retardants in wastewater. Two environmental engineering projects will investigate novel methods of improving drinking water treatment. Finally, the best management practices of improving water provision resiliency will be the focus of the anthropology project. By the end of the REU the students will be able to present and communicate their research results at regional/national conferences with the intent of future publication in academic journals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Title: REU Site: Water sustainability in the urban environment: Improving the sustainable use of water through interdisciplinary research
PI: Philip van Beynen, Co-PI: Jennifer Collins
Awardee: University of South Florida
Award Number: 1950458

Project Outcomes

Overview

For the summers of 2021-2023, a total of 24 undergraduate students from across the USA came to the University of South Florida to work with scholars on their research projects pertaining to improving the sustainability of water use in urban environments. Of the 24, 90% were female students and nine in total were either Hispanic or African American. Some of the projects undertaken by the students included creating advanced methods in treating wastewater, testing the effectiveness of constructed wetlands in treating this waste, determining human impacts on urban springs, how urban forests can reduce urban flooding and community engagement in water resources. Student involvement in the projects promoted their interest in STEM programs and lead a significant number to attend graduate school. 

Outcomes

Each summers cohort members were paired in individual research faculty and their graduate students to work on the latest project being undertaken by the professors. For nine weeks they conducted laboratory experiments, carried out fieldwork to collect water samples or conducted surveys of communities. Following the data production, students were taught how to analyze their data and create effective methods of reporting their research results. The climax of the summer was for the students to present their findings in poster form at a university research symposium.   

After the completion of their summer’s research experience, students were encouraged to attend regional or national academic conferences allowing them to meet with other students and faculty with similar interests. Many of the students did take advantage of this opportunity with several even winning competitions for their research presentations.

Another outcome of the project was for students to get involved in the publication of their results with their faculty. While it is difficult for such endeavors due to the lengthy process of getting research published, some of the students were co-authors on academic articles.

Besides their research projects, the students had the chance to visit regional water resource managers to see how their research may help these managers make more informed decisions in their management of this vital resource. In addition, visits to non-governmental environmental groups highlighted the need for public education on how society impacts water and how they can work together to reduce that impact.     

Finally, as STEM education is the fundamental component of this project, we can report that most of the attendees have graduated with STEM degrees or are in their senior year. These degrees include Environmental Engineering, Environmental Science and Biology. Several of the earlier cohorts have completed masters degrees and are now entering Ph.D. programs. Others have started environmental-related careers.
